title: VC Daily: Question: Will More VCs Launch Their Own Crypto Funds?
text:
This week's question: On Wednesday, Andreessen Horowitz said general partner Katie Huan will be leaving the firm to start her own crypto-focused fund with a16z serving as a limited partner. Will venture capitalists follow Ms. Huan's move in spinning out to start their own crypto funds?

Please email responses to marc.vartabedian@wsj.com.

And now on to the news ...

Top News

BNPL under review. Just in time for the holiday season: a regulatory inquiry into "buy now, pay later" installment plans that are frequently offered to online shoppers, The Wall Street Journal reports. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Thursday said it launched an inquiry into such plans offered by Afterpay Ltd., Affirm Holdings Inc., Klarna Bank AB and other firms. It is the first regulatory action focused on the companies.

The bureau issued orders seeking information from the firms that would help it examine concerns such as the kind of role these plans play in increasing consumers' debt and how these companies use consumer data, the agency said.

Information from the companies would help the CFPB "report to the public about industry practices and risks," said Rohit Chopra, the agency's chief, in a written statement.

$325 Million

The amount raised by Rokt Pte Ltd., which develops marketing technology for online shopping, in a Series E funding as it prepares for a planned initial public offering. (WSJ)

Reddit Files Confidentially for IPO

Reddit Inc. said it has confidentially filed paperwork with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering, an announcement that comes at the tail end of a banner year for stock-market debuts, the Journal reports. The company said in a blog post that it had started the paperwork with the SEC, but didn't share any further details. "The number of shares to be offered and the price range for the proposed offering have not yet been determined," it said in the post. "The initial public offering is expected to occur after the SEC completes its review process, subject to market and other conditions." As of August, Reddit said it had a valuation of about $10 billion after raising more than $400 million from Fidelity Investments Inc. In February, the social-media company said it had raised about $500 million at a $6.5 billion valuation.

Mobile Commerce Platform Rezolve Reaches $2 Billion SPAC Deal to Go Public

Rezolve Ltd. is combining with a special-purpose acquisition company to go public in a merger that values the mobile commerce platform at about $2 billion, the companies said, WSJ reports. A software platform that can turn physical advertisements and products into shoppable merchandise, Rezolve is merging with the SPAC Armada Acquisition Corp. I, a blank-check firm focused on the financial-technology industry. The deal is set to be unveiled Friday.

Alt text.

Space Industry's Banner Year: What Comes Next?

There have been more human space flights this year than any other, and private companies with paying customers are starting to make their mark on the industry. So what comes next for the space sector and humanity's ambitions among the stars? WSJ aerospace reporter Micah Maidenberg joins host Zoe Thomas to discuss.

Industry News

Funds

Anthemis Group, a New York City-based investment firm focused on the financial system has closed multiple funds. Combined, the total raises exceed $700 million, bringing the firm's assets under management to $1.2 billion.

Swiftarc Ventures has started fundraising for a telehealth fund. Swiftarc said the fund's areas of initial focus are obesity, pediatrics, and mental and behavioral health. The firm said it will select companies across the fields of telehealth/virtual care, virtual mental health, remote patient monitoring, chronic care management, and in-home evaluations and diagnostics.

People

Relevance Ventures, has appointed Consuelo Vanderbilt Costin to its board of directors. Ms. Costin co-founded SohoMuse, a social networking platform for creative professionals.

New Money

CData Software, a Chapel Hill, N.C.-based cloud solutions startup, raised a $140 million Series B funding round led by Updata Partners.

Noname Security, a Palo Alto, Calif.-based security company, raised $135 million in a Series C funding at a $1 billion valuation. The round was led by Georgian Partners Growth LP and Lightspeed Venture Partners, with participation from investors including Insight Partners, venture firm Cyberstarts, Next47, Forgepoint Capital and the Syndicate Group.

Mythic Therapeutics Inc. has raised $103 million in Series B financing with a goal of developing new types of drugs that use an antibody to deliver cancer drugs to tumors. Waltham, Mass.-based Mythic says its technology enables it to make antibody-drug conjugates safer and more effective by increasing the amount of the product that is internalized by diseased tissue. This results in less of the drug being released in healthy tissue, according to the company. Mythic, whose lead drug is a potential lung-cancer treatment, raised this financing from Viking Global Investors, which led the round, along with several other investors, including Venrock, Foresite Capital and OMX Ventures.

CartoDB Inc., a New York City-based spatial analysis platform, raised a $61 million Series C round led by Insight Partners, with participation from the European Investment Fund, Accel, Salesforce Ventures, Hearst Ventures, Earlybird VC Management and Kibo Ventures.

Famly, a Denmark-based child care software startup, raised an $18 million Series A investment led by Susquehanna Growth Equity. Investors including the founders of Zendesk Inc. participated in the deal.

Edge Gaming, a personalized gaming platform, was seeded with a $10 million investment. Mobile gaming company Playtika led the round, and was joined by Stardom Ventures and AnD Ventures.

Qonsent Inc., a New York City-based data privacy management startup, raised $5 million in seed funding from Zekavat Investment Group, Crosscut Ventures, Brand New Matter and Lunch Partners, among other investors.

Worca Inc., a Los Angeles human resources startup, raised $1.5 million in seed funding from Mucker Capital, Hyphen Capital and Gaingels Management.

Tech News

An artificial-intelligence event at the RISE tech conference in 2018. Next year's RISE conference in Hong Kong is being delayed.

Hong Kong tech conference postponed as pandemic restrictions isolate business hub

TikTok to adjust its algorithm to avoid negative reinforcement

Waste and recycling platform Rubicon going public in $2 billion SPAC merger

Xerox announces multiyear cloud deal with Oracle

U.S. blacklists dozens of Chinese entities over surveillance, military work

Netflix slashes India prices in battle with Amazon, Disney

Sidewalk Labs CEO Daniel Doctoroff to step down because of likely ALS
